entry.title: SAP on SQL Server 2025 with ODBC Driver 18: How to Implement the Encryption Requirements
entry.content:
With the release of SQL Server 2025, the SQL Server ODBC Driver version 18 is becoming more prevalent. ODBC Driver 18 introduces encryption by default, which has a crucial impact on SAP NetWeaver installations using SAP Software Provisioning Manager (SWPM).

There is some general guidance from Microsoft about this topic, but in this blog post, I’d like to outline the most basic way of configuring certificates on your hosts in more detail.

Note:
There are several ways to approach this, depending on your overall security concept. In this blog post, I describe what I consider the easiest method.

Context

ODBC Driver 18 requires encrypted connections, unlike its predecessor, Driver 17, where encryption is optional. This means you must configure certificates on your hosts to establish a secure connection from SWPM to the database.
Read on to learn the exact steps you need to take.

Step-by-Step: Configuring Certificates

1. Create a self-signed certificate:

Begin by generating a self-signed certificate on your database host using PowerShell:

a. At first, define the parameters for your certificate:

# Define parameters
$certificateParams = @{
    Type = "SSLServerAuthentication"
    Subject = "CN=$env:COMPUTERNAME"
    DnsName = @("$($env:COMPUTERNAME)", $([System.Net.Dns]::GetHostEntry('').HostName), 'localhost')
    KeyAlgorithm = "RSA"
    KeyLength = 2048
    HashAlgorithm = "SHA256"
    TextExtension = "2.5.29.37={text}1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.1"
    NotAfter = (Get-Date).AddMonths(36)
    KeySpec = "KeyExchange"
    Provider = "Microsoft RSA SChannel Cryptographic Provider"
    CertStoreLocation = "cert:\LocalMachine\My"
}​

b. For distributed or high availability (HA) installations, add all other hosts and virtual names to the DnsName property:

# Add additional hosts for distributed or clustered installations:
$certificateParams.DnsName += "<additional host or virtual name>​"

Repeat this command for all other nodes, application server hosts, and the virtual name of the SQL Server, if it's clustered or you use Always On.

c. Then create the certificate with this command:

# Create the certificate:
$cert = New-SelfSignedCertificate @certificateParams​

 

2. Export and import the certificate:

a. Export the certificate and import it into the trusted root store:

# Set a password:
$certPassword = ConvertTo-SecureString -String "<password>" -Force -AsPlainText 
$path = "cert:\localMachine\my\" + $cert.thumbprint

# Export the certificate to your disk
Export-PfxCertificate -cert $path -FilePath "C:\windows\temp\SQLcert.pfx" -Force -Password $certPassword

# Import the certificate into root from the disk:
Import-PfxCertificate -FilePath "C:\windows\temp\SQLcert.pfx" -Password $certPassword -CertStoreLocation "Cert:\LocalMachine\Root"

Ensure you use a secure password and choose an appropriate export location.

b. For distributed or HA installations, copy the SQLcert.pfx file to all necessary hosts and import the certificate similarly.

3. Configure SQL Server to use the certificate:

  1. Access the SQL Server Configuration Manager on the database host and navigate to "SQL Server Network Configuration".
  2. Open the properties of the protocols for your instance.
  3. Select the self-signed certificate from the Certificates tab.
  4. Restart SQL Server for the changes to take effect.

Now that you have the required encryption certificates in place, you can establish a secure connection from SWPM to your SQL Server database.

Conclusion

While the mandatory encryption setting may seem daunting, following these steps will ensure a smooth transition to ODBC Driver 18 and secure connections. If you prefer, you can opt for ODBC Driver 17, which offers optional encryption.

entry.title: Understanding the Evolution of SAP SuccessFactors BizX Architecture
entry.content:
Hi Community,

I’d like to share some observations and implementation insights on the evolution of the SAP SuccessFactors BizX architecture.

I often receive similar questions from clients and junior consultants:

  • “Since data already exists in Employee Central, why can’t PMGM read it directly?”
  • “If all modules are within SuccessFactors, why can’t RCM consume MDF data from EC—or send data back to EC?”
  • “Why are Business Rules not available for Background Elements?”
  • “Why does SuccessFactors have both Background Elements and MDF when they seem to serve similar purposes?”

Although in SAP marketing materials, EC is the foundation of all SF modules, it is not entirely the case. 

SF BizX architecture has involved overtime:

Phase 1: Original SF architecture: XML, route map, form based permission. (Prior to 2011 when SAP acquired SF)

  • Employee master data: UDF and background elements, trend information
  • Back then SF was a talent-focused system only. It consisted of PMGM (flagship module), SP, CDP, COMP, RCM. COMP module got enhanced overtime, it is perfectly integrated with EC and MDF. However, until 2H2025 PMGM, SP, CDP, RCM are still not truly integrated with EC or MDF. 

Phase 2: More framework was introduced (Foundation object, EC HRIS Element, Role based permission). (2011-2013 SAP built EC)

  • Employee master data: EC HRIS Element is added.
  • EC is built on top of UDF and syncs back to UDF. 

Phase 3: More framework was introduced (MDF, business rule, Role based permission). (2014 onwards)

  • Employee master data is now complete
    • UDF
    • HRIS Elements
    • Background Elements
    • Trend Elements
    • MDF (user transactional objects)
  • In 2015, SAP announced that all new SuccessFactors innovation would be based on MDF and started to migrate some legacy objects to MDF. New modules are built on MDF framework (Time off, time tracking, ONB, Opportunity market place etc) 
  • This is the reason why certain similar objects are built on different frameworks. E.g. Recurring Payment and One‑Time Payment are built as HRIS Elements whereas Recurring Deduction and One‑Time Deduction are built as MDF

Original SuccessFactors BizX Talent Module Architecture Diagram

 

2H2025 SuccessFactors BizX Module Architecture Diagram

 

Conclusion: BizX architecture has evolved significantly over the years. The combination of MDF and Business Rules together with Integration Center or CPI is extremely powerful and allows consultants to design highly customized solutions. However, It is a challenge for solution architects to keep in mind the coexistence of so many frameworks and how to design which data built on which framework carefully and holistically. 

A few considerations for design principle:

  • Always try to convince client to keep talent data in background element as talent module can only read background elements
  • There are only 15 custom fields in UDF. Reserve them for talent and IAS usage only. Other modules can directly get from HRIS elements. 
  • BIB/PTP and contingent workers cannot consume background elements. 
  • Using IC/CPI to replicate MDF to the background element or vice versa is technically possible. However, it should be avoided as much as possible. 

 

This article reflects my personal understanding and implementation experience with SAP SuccessFactors. I welcome feedback, challenges, and corrections from fellow consultants.

entry.title: SAP UI5 - QUnit-Testing
entry.content:
• 1. Setup
  • 1.1 Installing the required libraries
  • 1.2 Folder structure
  • 1.2.1 AllTests.js
  • 1.2.2 unitTests.qunit.html
  • 1.2.3 unitTests.qunit.js
  • 2. Implementing unit tests
  • 2.1 Basic structure of a test module
  • 2.2 Simple Test using sinon.stub and sinon.spy
  • 2.3 Testing functions with Return Values or Promises
  • 2.4 Testing error cases and exceptions
  • 2.5 Larger example with more branches
  • 3. Running tests and coverage
  • 3.1 Running tests
  • 3.2 Test results in the QUnit interface
  • 3.3 Enabling code coverage
  • 3.4 Detailed view of individual files
  • 3.5 Coverage reports
  • 4. Conclusion

In this post, I share practical experience with QUnit tests from my UI5 projects.
This post is aimed at developers who are already familiar with SAP UI5 and just getting started with QUnit. It was originally intended as an onboarding guide, but I noticed that information on this topic is quite scattered.
The examples in this post are kept close to real project code and can also be used as a reference when implementing similar test cases.

 

1. Setup

1.1 Installing the required libraries

To implement and execute QUnit tests in a UI5 application, just a few libraries are needed.
We just add them to the dependencies section of the application's package.json.

Depending on the project, either a specific version or simply latest can be used.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For later test coverage analysis (see section 3. Running Tests & Coverage), an additional library should be included:

 

 

 

 

 

 

This library also needs to be added to the ui5.yaml under "server>customMiddleware>".

 

 

After adding the required libraries, they can be installed using:

npm install

 

1.2 Folder structure

The folder structure for the unit tests is quite simple and is set up as follows:

- webapp
   - test
      - unit
         AllTests.js
         unitTests.qunit.html
         unitTests.qunit.js

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The actual test files should ideally follow a structure similar to the application itself.
This not a rule -> just for readability
For example, if unit tests are required for BaseController.js, a corresponding folder controller and a file BaseController.js should be created inside the test directory:

- webapp
   - controller
      BaseController.js

   - test
      - unit
         - controller
            BaseController.js

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

1.2.1 AllTests.js

All QUnit tests to be executed are included in the define section of this file.
It is a central place where we can enable or disable tests for execution.

sap.ui.define([
    "./controller/BaseController",
    // "./controller/OtherController",
    // "./controller/OtherController2",
    // "./services/SampleService",
    // "./util/SampleFormatter",
], function () {
    "use strict";
});

(Tip)

When working on unit tests for a specific controller an running them frequently, tests for other controllers can be commented out here, so they are not executed each time.

 

1.2.2 unitTests.qunit.html

Short and simple: we start our tests using this file.
All required libraries for test execution are included here.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <title>Unit tests for Template</title>
    <meta charset="utf-8">

    <script id="sap-ui-bootstrap"
        src="../../../../resources/sap-ui-core.js"
        data-sap-ui-resourceroots='{
            "app.unittester": "../"
        }'
        data-sap-ui-async="true"
        data-sap-ui-preload="async">
    </script>

    <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/qunit-2.css">

    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/qunit-2.js"></script>
    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/qunit/qunit-junit.js"></script>
    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon.js"></script>
    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon-qunit.js"></script>

    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/qunit/qunit-coverage-istanbul.js"
        data-sap-ui-cover-only="app/unittester/"
        data-sap-ui-cover-never="app/unittester/test, app/unittester/localServices, app/unittester/services">
    </script>

    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon.js"></script>
    <script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon-qunit.js"></script>

    <script src="unitTests.qunit.js"></script>
</head>

<body>
    <div id="qunit"></div>
    <div id="qunit-fixture"></div>
</body>
</html>

Just a few notes on the most important scripts that are included here (because we will use them later).

QUnit

<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/qunit-2.css">
<script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/qunit-2.js"></script>
<script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/qunit/qunit-junit.js"></script>

(Roughly summarized) The actual QUnit framework is included here.

sinon and sinon-qunit

<script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon.js"></script>
<script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon-qunit.js"></script>

These libraries enable spying, stubbing and mocking dependencies.

qunit-coverage-istanbul.js (Code Coverage Integration)

<script src="../../../../resources/sap/ui/qunit/qunit-coverage-istanbul.js"
        data-sap-ui-cover-only="app/unittester/"
        data-sap-ui-cover-never="[
           app/unittester/test, 
           app/unittester/localServices, 
           app/unittester/services
        ]">
</script>

This is required later for code coverage.

(Note) In this post, we use Istanbul for code coverage.
Of course, other options such as Karma can also be used if desired.

Important attributes:

  • data-sap-ui-cover-only
    files to be included in the coverage
  • data-sap-ui-cover-never
    files and directories to be excluded from coverage

 

1.2.3 unitTests.qunit.js

This is the central entry point for the unit tests.
Here we only include the tests from AllTests.js in the define section and start the test run.

QUnit.config.autostart = false;

sap.ui.getCore().attachInit(function () {
    "use strict";

    sap.ui.require([
        "app/unittester/test/unit/AllTests"
    ], function () {
        QUnit.start();
    });
});

2. Implementing unit tests

In this example, we will look at some unit tests for the BaseController as well as the basic structure.
In addition, we will see how sinon can be used to handle dependencies.

2.1 Basic structure of a test module

Each module has its own tests and provides lifecycle hooks such as beforeEach and afterEach.
The modules can be structured freely, depending on the requirements.

We start with a test module for BaseController.js and implement the module in the test file.
(webapp>test>unit>controller>BaseController)

sap.ui.define([
	"app/unittester/controller/BaseController",
	"sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon",
	"sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon-qunit",
], function(BaseController) {
	"use strict";
	
	/**
	* Module
	*/
	QUnit.module("Module", {
	   beforeEach: function() {
		  this.oBaseController = new BaseController();
	   },
	   afterEach: function() {
		  this.oBaseController.destroy();
	   }
	});
	
});

First, we include the actual BaseController and the two sinon libraries in the define statement.

After that, the module itself:
The lifecycle functions of the module are executed before and after each test.
In order to test the functions of the BaseController, we instatiate it before the test and destroy it afterwards.

2.2 Simple Test using sinon.stub and sinon.spy

In our first test, we will take the getRouter function from our BaseController.

getRouter: function() {
	return this.getOwnerComponent().getRouter();
},

We only want to test whether the function can be executed.

However, it has two dependencies:
this.getOwnerComponent and its function getRouter.

In order to test getRouter without having to instantiate all dependencies, we will "simulate" them with sinon.

This would look like the following:

sap.ui.define([
	"app/unittester/controller/BaseController",
	"sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon",
	"sap/ui/thirdparty/sinon-qunit",
], function(BaseController) {
	"use strict";
	
	/**
	* Module
	*/
	QUnit.module("Module", {
	   beforeEach: function() {
		  this.oBaseController = new BaseController();
	   },
	   afterEach: function() {
		  this.oBaseController.destroy();
	   }
	});
	
	/**
	* BaseController - Check getRouter
	*/
	QUnit.test("BaseController - Check getRouter", function(assert) {
	   sinon.stub(this.oBaseController, "getOwnerComponent").returns({
		  getRouter: sinon.stub()
	   });

	   const fnSpy = sinon.spy(this.oBaseController, "getRouter");
	   this.oBaseController.getRouter();
	   assert.ok(fnSpy.calledOnce, "Check getRouter successful");
	});
	
});

The function flow:

In line 24, we create a stub for this.oBaseController (our controller instance) and listen for calls to the getOwnerComponent function.
As soon as this function is executed, a return value is "simulated" that provides another simulated function, getRouter.

After that, we create a spy for this.oBaseController, that listens for calls to the getRouter function.

Then comes the actual function call in line 29.

Finally, we use an assertion where we check (via fnSpy.calledOnce) whether getRouter was executed at least once within the function.

And that's basically it. Every following test has the same structure (sometimes more or less complex).

Running the test:
If we look at the coverage here now (more on this later), we can see that the function was executed exactly once:

 

 

 

2.3 Testing functions with Return Values or Promises

Many controller methods are asynchronous and return a Promise.

These tests are implemented using async and await.
Using await ensures that the test waits properly for execution to finish.

Example: onStartEditMode

onStartEditMode: async function () {
	try {
		this._fireSetViewBusy(true);
		await this.oDraftManager.onEdit();
	} catch (oError) {
		this.evaluateException(oError);				
	} finally {
		this._fireSetViewBusy(false);				
	}						
},

The corresponding test:

QUnit.test("BaseController - Start edit mode", async function (assert) {
	sinon.stub(this.oBaseController, "_fireSetViewBusy");
	sinon.stub(this.oBaseController, "evaluateException");

	this.oBaseController.oDraftManager = {
		onEdit: sinon.stub().returns(Promise.resolve(true))
	};		

	const fnSpy = sinon.spy(this.oBaseController, "onStartEditMode");
	await this.oBaseController.onStartEditMode();
	assert.ok(fnSpy.calledOnce, "onStartEditMode executed successfully");
});

2.4 Testing error cases and exceptions

Error cases are just as important as successful scenarios.

In this example, we provoke an error by not stubbing any dependencies, so the function runs into the error path.
This verifies that the error handling logic is executed correctly.

Example function onFullScreenPressed:

onFullScreenPressed: function() {
	try {
		this._fireSetLayout("MidColumnFullScreen");
		this.getOwnerComponent().getModel("util").setProperty(`/ViewControl/Layout`, "MidColumnFullScreen");
		return true;
	} catch (oError) {
		this.evaluateException(oError);
		return false;
	}
},

The test:

QUnit.test("BaseController - Check onFullScreenPressed Exception", async function(assert) {
	assert.notOk(await this.oBaseController.onFullScreenPressed(), "Check onFullScreenPressed Exception successful");
});

2.5 Larger example with more branches

A slightly larger example is the onCancel function, which is a bit more complex. 

The function checks whether changes exist in the current draft.

Several paths (branches):
Changes exist: the user is shown a dialog, where they can decide whether to discard the draft
No changes: the draft is discarded
Error case: an error message is shown

onCancel:

onCancel: async function(oEvent) {
	try {
		const oData = this.getView().getBindingContext().getObject();

		//are there changes?
		if (oData.DraftEntityCreationDateTime.toString() !== oData.DraftEntityLastChangeDateTime.toString()) {
			const oSource = oEvent.getSource();
			this._openDiscardDraftDialog(oSource);
			return true;
		} else {
			//no changes, so discard the draft
			return Promise.resolve(await this.onDiscardDraft());
		}
	} catch (oError) {
		this.evaluateException(oError);
		return false;
	}
},

We will now test all paths to achieve full coverage.

1. onCancel with draft changes

/**
 * BaseController - Check onCancel (with draft changes)
 */
QUnit.test("BaseController - Check onCancel - with draft changes", async function(assert) {
	this.oBaseController.onDiscardDraft = sinon.stub().returns(Promise.resolve(true));
	sinon.stub(this.oBaseController, "_openDiscardDraftDialog");
	sinon.stub(this.oBaseController, "getView").returns({
		getBindingContext: sinon.stub().returns({
			getObject: sinon.stub().returns({
				DraftEntityCreationDateTime: 1,
				DraftEntityLastChangeDateTime: 2
			})
		})
	});
	const oMockButton = new Button();
	const oEvent = {
		getSource: function() {
			return oMockButton;
		}
	};

	assert.ok(await this.oBaseController.onCancel(oEvent), "Check onCancel (with draft changes) successful");
});

2. onCancel without changes

/**
 * BaseController - Check onCancel (no draft changes)
 */
QUnit.test("BaseController - Check onCancel - no changes", async function(assert) {
	this.oBaseController.onDiscardDraft = sinon.stub().returns(Promise.resolve(true));
	sinon.stub(this.oBaseController, "getView").returns({
		getBindingContext: sinon.stub().returns({
			getObject: sinon.stub().returns({
				DraftEntityCreationDateTime: 1,
				DraftEntityLastChangeDateTime: 1
			})
		})
	});

	assert.ok(await this.oBaseController.onCancel(), "Check onCancel (no draft changes) successful");
});

3. onCancel error case

/**
 * BaseController - Check onCancel Exception
 */
QUnit.test("BaseController - Check onCancel Exception", async function(assert) {
	assert.notOk(await this.oBaseController.onCancel(), "Check onCancel Exception successful");
});

When we now run the tests, we can see that we have covered all paths (branches):

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

3. Running tests and coverage

Unit tests can be executed in different ways.
In practice, running them via an npm script has proven to be the most convenient option.

3.1 Running tests

Unit tests can be started using a script defined in package.json:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The test run is then started using the following command:

npm run unit-tests

Once the tests are started, the browser opens and all tests (that are not commented out in AllTests.js) are executed automatically.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

3.2 Test results in the QUnit interface

After the tests have been executed, an overview is displayed in the browser showing which tests were successful an which were not.
This is also indicated by colors and shown together with an error message.

Example:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Failed tests can also be inspected in the browser console.

 

3.3 Enabling code coverage

Code coverage can be enabled using the checkbox "Enable coverage" in the QUnit toolbar.

 

 


Once enabled, tests are re-run automatically and an interactive coverage overview is displayed below the test results.

 

 

 

In the coverage overview, we can see the tested controllers and the information about the coverage itself.

statements and lines
Shows which lines of code were executed during the tests.

 

 

 

 

 

functions
Indicates which functions were called at least once.

 

 

branches
Shows whether different execution paths (e.g. if/else, try/catch) were actually tested.

 

 

 

3.4 Detailed view of individual files

Clicking a file opens a detailed coverage view.


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

green lines were executed
red lines were not covered

 

 

 

 

 

 

3.5 Coverage reports

In addition to the browser view, a coverage report is generated under:
tmp/coverage-reports/html/index.html

Alternatevly, it can also be found in the IDE's project folder:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

The report is updated automatically, can be opened in the browser independently.

4. Conclusion

With QUnit, we mainly focus on isolated controller logic and function behavior. 
Therefore keeping functions cleanly encapsulated and dependencies low during development leads to much easier unit tests

A note on coverage:
I know that coverage percentages are often defined as targets.
I have also seen that the temptation to push these numbers can be quite high by starting to test trivial functions (e.g. getters or setters). This usually backfires sooner or later.
It makes much more sense to focus on testing critical logic, error cases and especially different paths and branches.

entry.title: Step-By-Step Guide to Create SAP Integration Suite Trial Account and Assigning Required Roles
entry.content:
Introduction:

SAP Integration Suite provides a powerful set of capabilities to build, manage, and monitor integrations across cloud and on-premise systems. For developers and learners who want to explore these features, SAP offers a free trial account on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

However, beginners may face challenges after creating the trial account such as missing features, authorization errors, or not being able to access Cloud Integration, Trading Partner Management, or Integration Advisor. These issues are mostly related to capability enablement and role assignments.

In this blog, I will provide a step-by-step guide to setting up an SAP Integration Suite trial account and assign the required roles to successfully access Cloud Integration (CPI), Trading Partner Management (TPM), and Integration Advisor. This blog is also part of a series focused on TPM V2 in SAP CPI, starting from environment setup to end-to-end implementation.

Create SAP BTP Trail Account

Step 1: Access SAP BTP Trail

  1. Navigate to the SAP Business Technology Platform(BTP) Trail account and login using your SAP user ID.(SAP BTP Trail Account)
    If you are a first-time user, complete the registration by providing the required details and verifying your email address. Once verified, login to continue with the trail setup.
  2. Enter Mail ID(if you have an account already, skip to Step 2). Click on Next.
  3. Provide all details and click on submit:
  4. After you submit, an email will be sent to the address you provided.
  5. Check your email inbox for a verification email, then click the link to verify your account, set your password, and continue.
  6. Verify your Phone number and Accept the terms and conditions.

Step 2: Choose Your Region and Create a Subaccount

  1. Select the region which you want and click on Create Account.

  2. It will take few minutes to create, click on continue and go to your trial account.

Step 3: Subscribe to Integration Suite

  • In your trial subaccount, navigate to Service Marketplace (under Services).

Search for Integration Suite, then click the three-dot menu and choose Create to subscribe.

Note:

  1. Integration Suite service in the trial version can only be subscribed to within a single subaccount. You cannot reuse it in multiple subaccounts. Currently, it is available only in the US East (VA) - AWS and Singapore - Azure regions.
  2. If you created a trial account more than 90 days ago and are setting up a new subaccount, Integration Suite may not appear in the Service Marketplace. If so, navigate to Entitlements → Edit, and add the Integration Suite entitlement manually.

Step 4: Assign Initial Role Collections to Your User

  1. Go to Security -> Select users -> Click Role Collection ->Click on 3dots -> Assign Role Collection.
  2. Select ‘Integration_Provisioner’ and click on Assign Role Collection.

Step 5: Enable Capabilities in Integration Suite

  1. Click on Instances & Subscriptions-> Click on go to application in Integration Suite.
  2. Click on Add Capabilities.
  3. Select the required capabilities -> Next -> Next -> Next -> Activate.
  4. It will take some time to active all the capabilities.

    Now you will be able to see all the capabilities. To access them we need to add roles to user.

Step 6: Assign Role Collections for Cloud Integration

  1. Go to Security -> Select users -> Click Role Collection ->Click on 3dots -> Assign Role Collection.

    Here I am Assigning the role collections only related to cloud integration, for other capabilities you may need to add other roles.

  2. Open the integration suite application, now you will be able to see all the options.(if you are not able to see logout and login again).

Step 7: Assign Role Collections for Integration Advisor

  1. Under Security -> Click Role Collections ->Click on create.
  2. Provide some name and create it.
  3. Search for created role collection name -> select -> edit.
    Role->ContentDeveloper

    Add your id to Users

    Here I am Assigning the role collections only related to Integration Advisor, for other capabilities you may need to add other roles.

  4. Open the integration suite application, now you will be able to see all the options.(if you are not able to see logout and login again).

Step 8: Assign Role Collections for Trading Partner Management

  1. Under Security -> Click Role Collections ->Click on create.
  2. Search for created role collection name -> select -> edit.
    Role-> AuthGroup_Administrator, AuthGroup_BusinessExpert, AuthGroup_ContentPublisher, AuthGroup_IntegrationDeveloper, AuthGroup_ReadOnly, AuthGroup_TenantPartnerDirectoryConfigurator.

    Add your id to Users

    Here I am Assigning the role collections only related to Trading Partner Management, for other capabilities you may need to add other roles.

  3. Open the integration suite application, now you will be able to see all the options.(if you are not able to see logout and login again).

Conclusion:
By following these steps, you can successfully set up an SAP Integration Suite trial account and enable Cloud Integration, Trading Partner Management, and Integration Advisor. By carefully subscribing to the necessary services, enabling required capabilities, and assigning the correct role collections, you ensure that you have full access to the tools you need right from the start.

This guide is part of a broader TPM V2 learning series, so stay tuned for future posts where we’ll dive deeper into configuring, designing, and deploying integration scenarios using the tools you’ve just enabled.

Happy learning and exploring SAP Integration Suite!

entry.title: Understanding GOS Attachments and Their Backend Tables in SAP ABAP
entry.content:
Introduction

Generic Object Services (GOS) play a crucial role in SAP by allowing users to attach documents, notes, and URLs to business objects such as Purchase Orders, Accounting Documents, Materials, and Customer Masters.
For ABAP developers and functional consultants, understanding how these attachments are stored and retrieved at the database level is essential for reporting, audits, migrations, and enhancements.

This article explains the core tables, object relationships, and practical ABAP insights related to GOS attachments.

What Are GOS Attachments?

GOS (Generic Object Services) enables users to:

  • Attach files (PDF, Excel, etc.)

  • Create notes

  • Link external documents

These attachments are visible via Services for Object in SAP GUI transactions like:

  • ME23N (Purchase Order)

  • FB03 (Accounting Document)

  • MM03 (Material Master)

Key Tables Used for GOS Attachments

1. SRGBTBREL – Relationship Table

This is the most important table for GOS.

  • Stores the relationship between:

    • Business Object (e.g., BUS2012, BKPF, KNA1)

    • Attachment or note

  • Common fields:

    • TYPEID_A – Business object type

    • INSTID_A – Object key (e.g., PO number, document number)

    • RELTYPE – ATTA (Attachment), NOTE, URL

✅ Used to check whether an attachment exists.

2. SOOD / SOFM / SOC3 (SAPoffice Documents)

  • Stores SAPoffice document metadata and content

  • Often used when attachments are created as SAPoffice objects

  • Can be read using:

    • SO_OBJECT_READ

    • SO_DOCUMENT_READ_API1

3. DRAD (DMS-Based Attachments)

If attachments are stored using Document Management System (DMS):

  • Table: DRAD

  • Object key may contain:

    • Material Number

    • Equipment

    • Other master data keys

How to Identify Attachments for a Business Object

Example: Purchase Order (ME23N)

  • Business Object: BUS2012

  • Table: SRGBTBREL

  • Filter:

    • TYPEID_A = 'BUS2012'

    • INSTID_A = <PO Number>

If an entry exists → attachment is present.

Common Use Cases

  • Audit reports to find documents without attachments

  • Mass download of attachments

  • Migration from Content Server / FileNet / SharePoint

  • Custom reports showing attachment count

  • Enhancing attachment list display

Important Notes

  • There is no direct T-code to attachment mapping

  • Attachments are linked to Business Objects, not transactions

  • Same attachment can be visible in multiple transactions

Conclusion

Understanding GOS attachment architecture helps SAP professionals build robust reports, support audits, and design scalable document solutions.
Tables like SRGBTBREL, SOOD, and DRAD are essential tools in every ABAP developer’s toolkit.

If you frequently work with attachments, mastering these relationships will save significant time and effort.

entry.title: Custom Entity With Actions
entry.content:
What is a Custom Entity in RAP? 

In the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP), a Custom Entity is a CDS entity that does not map to a database table. Instead, it represents virtual data provided by custom ABAP logic. It is used when: 

  • You need to expose calculated or external data. 
  • You want to integrate non-database sources (e.g., APIs, external systems). 
  • You require custom operations beyond standard CRUD. 

Adding an Action to a Custom Entity allows you to trigger specific business operations directly from the UI. 

Now we will look at one practical example for Custom Entity with an Action in RAP, where the action will be performed based on the user click on the button called CustomAction , when user clicks on it the icon will be changed. 

First, we will begin by creating a database table with the fields shown in the screenshot below. 

Next, we will create a Custom Entity and define its implementation class, as the Custom Entity will be realized through the logic implemented in that class "ZGA_CL_QRY_PRVD_C_ACT". 

Now, we will implement the logic in the class and use the mandatory interface IF_RAP_QUERY_PROVIDER to handle data retrieval for the Custom Entity. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

To adjust the data, we have implemented another class named ZGA_CL_BS_DEMO_ADJUST_DATA. 

Our next task is to create a Behavior Definition for the Custom Entity ZGA_I_CUST_ACT_DEMO to enable actions and logic implementation.

Next, we dive into implementing the Behavior Definition logic in the class ZBP_GA_I_CUST_ACT_DEMO. 

The class shown below serves as the buffer class, which we have utilized in our Behavior Implementation class.

Our next task is to create the Service Definition and Service Binding, enabling the UI to consume the Custom Entity and its actions.

 

Output:

Once an instance is selected, clicking CustomAction will dynamically update the icon, as displayed in the screenshot. 

The Reset button is used to restore all icons to their original state. 

Conclusion 

Custom Entities with Actions in SAP RAP provide a powerful way to implement dynamic, user-driven functionality without relying on database persistence. In this example, we demonstrated how to create a Custom Entity and enhance it with two actions. 

By leveraging actions, you can enrich your applications with flexible business logic, improve user engagement, and maintain a clean separation between UI and backend logic. This approach is ideal for scenarios where you need virtual data handling combined with interactive operations.

entry.title: Leveraging ADBC for High-Performance HANA Operations in ABAP
entry.content:
Introduction

ADBC (ABAP Database Connectivity) is a framework provided by SAP that allows direct execution of Native SQL statements from ABAP programs. Using ADBC, we can execute HANA-specific SQL queries, DML, DDL, and Stored Procedures directly from ABAP without relying on Open SQL.

ADBC is especially useful when:

  • We do not have access to ADT / HANA Studio
  • HANA is configured as a secondary database
  • We need to execute HANA-optimized SQL or procedures
  • Performance-critical logic cannot be handled using Open SQL

ADBC was introduced by SAP from NetWeaver 7.40 onwards.

Why ADBC instead of Open SQL?

Open SQL

ADBC

Database-independent

Database-specific

Limited SQL features

Full HANA SQL support

No stored procedure call

Can call stored procedures

Safer but restricted

Powerful but must be handled carefully

Architecture Overview

ADBC internally uses:

  • CL_SQL_CONNECTION → To establish DB connection
  • CL_SQL_STATEMENT → To execute SQL
  • CL_SQL_RESULT_SET → To fetch result data

Steps to be Followed for ADBC

REPORT zkadbc1.

DATA : ob1     TYPE REF TO cl_sql_connection,
       ob2     TYPE REF TO cl_sql_statement,
       ob3     TYPE REF TO cl_sql_result_set,
       ob_ex1  TYPE REF TO cx_sql_exception,
       ob_ex2  TYPE REF TO cx_parameter_invalid,
       ob_ex3  TYPE REF TO cx_parameter_invalid_type,
       v_sql   TYPE string,
       v_msg   TYPE string,
       it_kna1 TYPE TABLE OF kna1,
       wa_kna1 TYPE kna1,
       o_data  TYPE REF TO data,
       v_count TYPE i.

" 1st step SET THE CONNECTION TO THE DATABASE.
TRY.
    CALL METHOD cl_sql_connection=>get_connection
*    EXPORTING
*      con_name = 'ABC'         " Single-character indicator
      RECEIVING
        con_ref = ob1.                 " Connection Object
  CATCH cx_sql_exception.        " Exception Class for SQL Error
    CLEAR v_msg.
    CALL METHOD ob_ex1->if_message~get_text
      RECEIVING
        result = v_msg.
    WRITE :/ 'Short Exception msg is :', v_msg.
    CLEAR v_msg.
    CALL METHOD ob_ex1->if_message~get_longtext
      RECEIVING
        result = v_msg.
    WRITE :/ 'Long Exception msg is :', v_msg.

ENDTRY.
"  2nd step     Instantiate the statement class
IF ob1 IS BOUND.
  CREATE OBJECT ob2
    EXPORTING
      con_ref = ob1.
ENDIF.
"   3rd step
IF  ob2 IS BOUND.
  v_sql = 'SELECT * FROM KNA1'.
ENDIF.
* 4th Step.
TRY.
    CALL METHOD ob2->execute_query
      EXPORTING
        statement  = v_sql
      RECEIVING
        result_set = ob3.
  CATCH cx_sql_exception INTO ob_ex1.
    CLEAR v_msg.
    CALL METHOD ob_ex1->if_message~get_text
      RECEIVING
        result = v_msg.
    WRITE :/ 'Short Exception msg is :', v_msg.
    CLEAR v_msg.
    CALL METHOD ob_ex1->if_message~get_longtext
      RECEIVING
        result = v_msg.
    WRITE :/ 'Long Exception msg is :', v_msg.
    CLEAR v_msg.

  CATCH cx_parameter_invalid INTO ob_ex2.
    CLEAR v_msg.
    CALL METHOD ob_ex2->if_message~get_text
      RECEIVING
        result = v_msg.
    WRITE :/ 'Short Exception msg is :', v_msg.
    CLEAR v_msg.
    CALL METHOD ob_ex2->if_message~get_longtext
      RECEIVING
        result = v_msg.
    WRITE :/ 'Long Exception msg is :', v_msg.

ENDTRY.

IF ob3 IS  BOUND.
  GET REFERENCE OF it_kna1 INTO o_data.

  TRY.
      CALL METHOD ob3->set_param_table
        EXPORTING
          itab_ref = o_data.
    CATCH cx_parameter_invalid.
      CLEAR v_msg.
      CALL METHOD ob_ex2->if_message~get_text
        RECEIVING
          result = v_msg.
      WRITE :/ 'Short Exception msg is :', v_msg.
      CLEAR v_msg.
      CALL METHOD ob_ex2->if_message~get_longtext
        RECEIVING
          result = v_msg.
      WRITE :/ 'Long Exception msg is :', v_msg.
  ENDTRY.
  TRY.
      CALL METHOD ob3->next_package
        RECEIVING
          rows_ret = v_count.
    CATCH cx_sql_exception INTO ob_ex1.
      CLEAR v_msg.
    CALL METHOD ob_ex1->if_message~get_text
      RECEIVING
        result = v_msg.
    WRITE :/ 'Short Exception msg is :', v_msg.
    CLEAR v_msg.
    CALL METHOD ob_ex1->if_message~get_longtext
      RECEIVING
        result = v_msg.
    WRITE :/ 'Long Exception msg is :', v_msg.
    CATCH cx_parameter_invalid_type INTO ob_ex3.
      CLEAR v_msg.
    CALL METHOD ob_ex3->if_message~get_text
      RECEIVING
        result = v_msg.
    WRITE :/ 'Short Exception msg is :', v_msg.
    CLEAR v_msg.
    CALL METHOD ob_ex3->if_message~get_longtext
      RECEIVING
        result = v_msg.
    WRITE :/ 'Long Exception msg is :', v_msg.
  ENDTRY.

  IF it_kna1 is NOT INITIAL.
    FORMAT COLOR 3.
   WRITE :/ 'Number of count reterive : ', v_count.
   FORMAT COLOR OFF.
   ULINE.
   FORMAT COLOR 4.
   LOOP AT it_kna1 INTO wa_kna1.
     WRITE :/  wa_kna1-kunnr,
               wa_kna1-land1,
               wa_kna1-name1,
               wa_kna1-ort01.

   ENDLOOP.
   FORMAT COLOR OFF.
  ENDIF.
OB3->close( ).
ENDIF.
TRY.
CALL METHOD ob1->close
    .
  CATCH cx_sql_exception INTO ob_ex1 .
     CLEAR v_msg.
    CALL METHOD ob_ex1->if_message~get_text
      RECEIVING
        result = v_msg.
    WRITE :/ 'Short Exception msg is :', v_msg.
    CLEAR v_msg.
    CALL METHOD ob_ex1->if_message~get_longtext
      RECEIVING
        result = v_msg.
    WRITE :/ 'Long Exception msg is :', v_msg.
ENDTRY.

 

Establish Database Connection

Explanations
  • Establishes a connection to the current database
  • Works for:
    • Primary HANA database
    • Secondary HANA database

Returns a connection object in OBJ1
Prepare SQL Query

Explanation:

  • Native SQL query compatible with HANA
  • Directly accesses database table
  • Unlike Open SQL, client handling must be done manually if required.

Execute SELECT Query

Explanation:

  • EXECUTE_QUERY is used for:
    • SELECT statements
    • Stored procedures returning result sets
  • Returns a result set object (ob3)

Bind Result Set to Internal Table

 Why this is needed:

  • ADBC requires a generic data reference
  • Internal table reference is passed dynamically.

Close Database Connection

 Explanation:

  • Closes the database connection
  • Prevents session leaks
  • Always close connection in productive systems.

Conclusion

ADBC is a powerful bridge between ABAP and HANA, giving developers full control over database operations when Open SQL reaches its limits. When used carefully, it enables high-performance, flexible, and advanced database operations directly from ABAP.

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud’s 2025 Innovation and Impact: Celebrating AI-first B2B sales transformation
entry.content:
Looking back, 2025 innovation has clearly shaped how sales organizations can adopt game-changing AI capabilities and form forward looking strategies for practical adoption of AI. Our layered agentic strategy of embedded AI, customer experience AI, unified organizational/agentic orchestration, and Joule, has helped business create a clear phased adoption plan to match organizational readiness and maturity. The year also stands out as an exceptional year for truly inspiring customer success stories and go-lives, including significant and impactful use cases for AI enhanced capabilities.

Redefining Sales Engagement Through AI

SAP Sales Cloud innovations have opened the door to dramatically improve sales engagement, including average deal cycle duration, speed of engagement, quality of each interaction and more. It is no secret that agentic AI has quickly dominated the technology narrative with a buzz that has taken business applications by storm, but it’s critical that organizations ask the right questions and form the right business strategies. Key use cases, feature adoption, and overall orchestration are all critical topics. SAP Sales Cloud AI innovation is focused on a tiered approach so organizations can easily start adopting capabilities while laying the groundwork for an enterprise-wide AI strategy.  

AI order insights have been added to SAP Sales Cloud and use agentic and generative processes to provide deep order insights in real-time. A sales rep, or anyone on the account team for that matter, can easily view order updates, delays, and status, with the ability to understand the WHY behind the information. This helps improve the overall buyer experience and keeps expectations of all parties aligned. Additionally, it allows the sales rep to proactively address issues and reinforces the lasting value of the business relationship.

Agent builder is exactly what you would expect and provides users with a unified resource for AI Agent configuration. This powerful workspace is easy to use and provides a 5-step process that configures an Agent end-to-end, easily allowing businesses to adopt new capabilities and set up differentiating agentic use cases that move the needle.

AI duplicate check adds an extra layer to improve data integrity and uses AI to analyze records for duplicates and discrepancies. The deep-learning algorithm examines available data and uses intelligence to identify potential issues, allowing the user to easily review and approve or deny clean-up actions.

Joule has been dramatically enhanced and provides users with an AI-driven assistant for answers, updates, information capture, and more. Joule is available on desktop and through the dedicated SAP Sales Cloud mobile app, allowing users to use natural language and voice-to-text to increase productivity regardless of location. The Joule experience extends across SAP applications allowing users to take-action from the workspaces they use every day, instead of needing to go to multiple applications or through manual navigation.

Streamlining Lead-to-Cash with Smart Automation

Alongside AI-first innovation, SAP Sales Cloud has received substantial core feature improvements designed to increase flexibility and expand functionality. These enhancements help increase operational efficiency across the lead-to-cash process by removing barriers, deepening automation capabilities, and improving top-down sales execution, all while laying a foundation for greater AI infusion into these key processes in 2026 and beyond.  

Account Planning has been greatly enhanced with centralized Action Plans that help guide execution and improve engagement across the account team. Action plans provide direction and oversight while surfacing critical data. Showcased at SAP Connect 2025, Deep Research agentic capabilities worked in conjunction with SAP Sales Cloud account planning to improve data and offload manual tasks which continues to be an area of focus and enhancement.

Subscription Selling capabilities are linked with SAP CPQ to cover a wide range of advanced subscription-based sales models and solution offerings. These features provide a streamlined sales experience for sellers, allowing for simple configuration of advanced solution offerings in complex deals cycles. These enhancements further improve speed and accuracy of quotes.  

Sales target planning features within SAP Sales Cloud have also been extended, allowing for greater control and mapping of sales targets and quotas. Goal setting and segmentation options provide sales operations with flexible selections to best match go to market and pipeline generation strategies.

Volume pipeline management enhancements further help sales organizations monitor, analyze, and optimize pipeline flow and health. Taking the next step past analytics and visual exploration in the Pipeline Flow workspace, these dynamic features help organizations shift from tracking to planning and managing, improving visibility and impact.

Accelerating Sales Execution and Collaboration

B2B selling involves many individuals in many roles, both on the buying center and selling sides of the equation. AI-first innovation and continuous improvement of lead-to-cash processes are strategic priorities of our development roadmap, but we understand that B2B sales is fundamentally about connecting people. In this regard, we continue to focus on innovations that bring people together and foster collaboration.

Mobile extensibility – SAP Sales Cloud at the core is an AI first, cloud-native application with extensibility in mind, opening the door for organizations to essentially match any business need or fill specialized use cases. Alongside the dedicated SAP Sales Cloud mobile app, we have greatly increased extensibility for greater customization and integration at scale. These enhancements allow for greater agility and flexibility to support specialized mobile sales functions.

Teams chat and overall Microsoft Teams integration has been dramatically improved so users can stay in the workspace they prefer to use. Users can now send and receive Teams chats, both individual and group messages, directly within the embedded SAP Sales Cloud – Teams experience.  

Team calendar similarly helps sellers and sales managers stay in lock-step without needing to go to other workspaces. With team calendar, users have insight into calendar details, availability, and upcoming meeting as configured, while simultaneously removing gaps between SAP Sales Cloud and organization productivity tools.

Driving B2B sales in 2026 and beyond

Looking to 2026, in SAP Sales Cloud’s roadmap and planned development there is a lot to be excited about. Thematically it is largely shaped by bringing technology and people together. SAP Sales Cloud is and will continue to grow as a hybrid-intelligence application, uniting AI agents with critical use cases to accelerate sales performance and revenue generation. AI orchestration is top of mind and will help businesses improve adoption of AI capabilities and formulate forward looking business strategies. Working closely with our customers and partners, we expect to deliver innovations and enhancements that will improve B2B sales success and the overall customer experience.

entry.title: Travel Under Quarantine(TUQ): A supply chain concept of utilizing the quarantine time in Shipping
entry.content:
Abstract: This is a unique supply chain concept of utilizing the quarantine time in productive way to improve efficiency without additional investment by leveraging existed integrated supply‑chain technologies. It represents a paradigm shift for MedTech and pharmaceutical companies — moving from extended supply‑chain practices to an orchestrated supply chain that strengthens the company’s bottom line, better serves patient needs, and supports environmental sustainability.

In general, standard supply‑chain practice entails manufacturing followed by quality inspection and batch‑release activities. Production captures, records and documents all product and process related to Critical Quality Attributes (CQAs) documented. Following production completion, each batch is transferred to Quality for inspection and the batch’s shelf‑life countdown commences. To validate product conformity and other batch documentation is a quite lengthy process itself but unavoidable process to run the business complied manner.

Also many situations samples need to be sent to specialized laboratories to ensure conformities and Bio-Buurden*1 testing or Endotoxin testing *2  for medical devices. Similarly, other long‑lead‑time tests required for long‑term stability assessment of medical devices and pharmaceutical products are crucial for determining shelf life and ensuring that products remain safe and effective during storage and use; such testing is essential to establish and verify that a product retains its intended characteristics for a specified period under defined storage conditions. This is required to demonstrate compliance with applicable national, regional, and statutory /regulatory requirements.

This process typically requires 2-6 weeks and sometimes longer. For established products manufactured in pre-validated production line with approved production recipes, 99% of cases of those test results show promising result.

Improvement Opportunity: As illustrated in Diagram 1, instead of quarantine a batch under quality stock at the manufacturing facility or a sterilization site, or a 3PL/4PL logistics location, the manufactured, sellable batches can be moved from the manufacturing site to an OTC site through systematically controlled shipping process (for example, shipped to  a primary distribution center or a company/affiliate-owned DC within the company distribution network). Physical inventory deployment /shipment typically takes an additional 2–4 weeks to reach global hub DCs. Once the batch is released post arrival of the product, the product becomes immediately available for customer fulfillment, effectively providing customers with an extra 4–6 weeks of usable shelf life.

 

Challenges :

  • Conservative mindset; limited evaluation of SAP’s integration capabilities across the supply chain nodes.
  • Heterogeneous and fragmented supply chain Eco-system.
  • Siloed operations and manual controls across manufacturing and OTC sites, including separate systems and ownership.
  • Separate QMS procedures and standard operating procedures for manufacturing sites and distribution Hubs.

Diagram 1 :: Schematic illustration for conventional manufacturing and Batch Release (Process times are shown in Weeks)

 

Why should the industry care about this?

On average, the pharmaceutical industry experiences value leakage of about 2% to 5%, which amounts to hundreds of billions annually worldwide, driven largely by expiry and distribution inefficiencies. If the unproductive idle time in the supply chain can be repurposed under appropriate controls, the usable life of medical devices, implants, and medicines could potentially be extended by approximately 4 to 6 weeks and redirected to patients in need, while optimizing supply-chain waste at no extra operational cost. This blog proposes a techno-functional solution in which product batches are assigned and routed to company and affiliate distribution centers and market hub DCs.

Before going into further technical details of the blog, let us understand few key elements of planning.

Acronym

Description

Definition

QI Stock

Quality Inspection Stock

Stock status before final quality release

CQA

Critical Quality attributes

Quality Parameters requirement to meet product conformity

NC

Non-Conformance

Product deviation from approved product specification

GxP

Good X Practice

X represents Manufacturing, Laboratory, Clinical etc.

DC

Distribution Center

Supply chain entity responsible for distribution of products for defined geo location.

TUQ

Travel Under Quarantine

Allowed systematically controlled shipment of inventory prior to final quality release.

GR

Goods Receipt

Receiving inventory in systematic locations

 

  1. Shelf Life and Expiry date

Chemical and physical property of pharmaceutical products retain their permissible characteristics up to a finite number of days which is determined empirically based on clinical and laboratory experiments and trials is called Shelf life. Last date marks the last day of the batch’s specified shelf life is exhausted.

Expiry Date = Date of Manufacturing + Shelf Life (usually maintained in number days)

  1. Remaining shelf life : No of days left before a batch becomes unusable, calculated from the current date until its expiration date.
  1. Customer specific shelf life:No of days minimum remaining days of shelf life customer wants when customer receives the product.

What is Travel under quarantine: Allowed systematically controlled shipment of inventory prior to final quality release with stringent quarantine control comply with quality system requirement and all statutory/regulatory guideline across the geographies. Also ensure 100% patient safety.

Diagram 2 :: Schematic illustration of proposed solution(Process times are shown in Weeks).

 

Techno-functional Solution in SAP S/4 :This is a cross-module techno functional solution using standard SAP provided features which would be leveraged internal manufacturing and subcontracting manufacturing along with IM managed location, or embedded eWM or decentralized eWM.

Manufacturing process stays the same.

  1. Production order or Sub-contracting purchasing order requires to be created based on production plan receives from planning system.
  2. Recommended Inspection Choices
    1. 04- Goods Receipt Inspection from Production order with early lot creation (Inspection lot creation at production/process order release)
    2. 0130- Goods Receipt Inspection from Sub Contracted purchased order.
  3. Create two types of Master Inspection Characteristics
    1. Short Term Inspection characteristics: Inspection characteristics must be recorded before Usage Decision.
    2. Long Term Inspection Characteristics: Inspection characteristics to record
  4. Conduct inspection as per inspection as per Inspection plan.
  5. As soon as all short-term Inspections are done. Only long-term MICs have pending result recordings. Authorized Quality engineer can provide condition UD with UD code “TUQ- Travel Under Quarantine) with follow-on function to set the batch status to restricted.
    1. Conditional UD : Usage decision conditionally releases the inventory from quality stock to unrestricted stock keeping the long characteristics open where  Inspection lot status stay open with status code “STIC/LTIN” *3
    2. If Long term inspection characteristics results are not meeting permissible quality criteria, then UD can be revoked and appropriate non-conformance (Quality notification) can be initiated with follow
  1. Conditional UD performed with custom UD code (Say : TUQ (Travel Under Quarantine).
  2. Add standard batch characteristics LOBM_UDCODE = TUQ which will automatically capture UDcode in batch record as soon as conditional UD executes.
  3. Logistics /Delivery now can create STO to deploy the inventory distribution center (Same system or separate OTC System)
  4. Enhancement: STO batch assignment and PGI must check only restricted batch with standard batch characteristics LOBM_UDCODE Value = “TUQ”,  and Inspection lot status = “STIC/LTIN”  else prevent batch assignment in STO/PGI.
  1. When Long Term characteristics result arrives quality engineer needs to record the result. There are two expected outcomes
    1. If results are within permissible limit, then complete the inspection lot and follow on function will Un-restricted batch.
      1.       Batch master integration will be fed to OTC system which un-restrict batch in OTC.
      2.       OTC team systematically notified and batch is available for customer orders.
    2. If results are deviated from permissible limit, them Open non-conformance .

Diagram 3: : Illustration of transactional Steps for post manufacturing completion.

 

 

Master data Requirements:

Quality Master data

  1. Inspection Type:
  • 04      - Goods Receipt from Production 
  • 0130 - Quality inspection for Subcontracting PO
  1. Master Inspection Characteristics:
    • Short term MICs
    • Long terms MIC
  2. Inspection Plan:
  • Inspection plan to be created in Plant, UoM and Inspection type combination.
  1. Material Master:
    • QM view

Make Master data:

  1. BOM
  2. Routing with external (operation if required)

Source and Logistics master data

  1. Infor records & source List
  2. Inter company stock transfer setup.

Conclusion:

This approach has been implemented in the United States and Europe by medical device and diagnostics companies and has produced three principal benefits:

  1. Extended shelf life for customer (Hospitals and consignment customers)
  2. Protect value leakage from scrapping of expired products there by creating =ve bottom line impact for the
  3. End of the day any kind of scraping has a implicit and explicit sizable environmental impact

This solution is not industry‑specific. It can also reduce inventory carrying costs, accelerate supply‑chain velocity, and improve inventory turnover in other industries.

entry.title: Re: Issue with Cross-Order Staging Determination During P...
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I have got the reason for this behavior. This is standard system behavior. When the manufacturing order has a batch or batch selection criteria, and cross-order staging is used, the system treats it as single-order staging. Accordingly, in the PMR, the system sets the STAGING_METHOD to ‘3’ (Single Order Only).

Also, SAP providing two BAdi related to this, /SCWM/EX_MFG_STAGE_METHOD and /SCWM/EX_MFG_STAGE_INFO. ( refer SAP note-3021925 - Dependency for BAdI Implementation Unclear)

Please refer this SAP note - 3529286 - PMR items created with Single-Order Staging method while Cross-Order Staging is expected.

Refer this discussion 

Best regards,

Kannan chokkanathan.

entry.title: 🇮🇳 Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core (Pune, India)
entry.content:
This SAP CodeJam event is on Getting Started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core and Python. You do not need any background in the topic, but you should have a lot of curiosity!

In this CodeJam, you will learn how to use the Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core to implement retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). This approach improves the responses of large language models (LLMs) and reduces hallucinations. You will learn how to deploy an LLM and the orchestration service on SAP AI Core, and how to query it via SAP AI Launchpad and the Python SDK. Additionally, you will gain insights into key generative AI concepts and learn how to enhance RAG responses.

Location and Date:

This is a free in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Tuesday, February 10th, 2026 from 10:00 - 16:30 hrs  local time in Pune, India. The language of the event and the content will be English.

entry.title: Re: How system make to consider planned delivery time int...
entry.content:
Could you please elaborate on the specific reasons why this solution does not fit? For example, is it due to multiple raw materials with varying lead times, system constraints, or process alignment issues?

In parallel, there are alternate approaches we can consider:

  • Maintain planned delivery times at raw material level so MRP offsets dependent requirements correctly.
  • Use scheduling margin keys or safety time to introduce buffers without inflating GR processing time.
  • Explore PP/DS (Production Planning and Detailed Scheduling) if more granular pegging and scheduling is required.

Once I understand the exact limitation, I can try to assist with the most suitable option that ensures raw material delivery times are properly considered in planned order scheduling.

entry.title: Re: Template not available
entry.content:
In order to submit a service request for these templates, an S-user must have the authorization 'Create Billable Service Requests' at the customer number level. To obtain this required authorization, please contact your administrator (listed under Users & Contacts - SAP for Me) to have the authorization assigned.

For more detailed information on S-user authorizations required the Private Cloud Service Request application, please refer to KBA 2669783 - Required S-user authorizations for the Private Cloud Service Request application - SAP for Me

entry.title: Re: RAP: How to enable/disable a field when entering a va...
entry.content:
For Example:

field ( features : instance ) NRooms;

 will trigger method GET_INSTANCE_FEATURES

RESULT = VALUE #( FOR ENTITY IN LT_BOOKING_RESULT
( %TKY = ENTITY-%TKY
%FEATURES-%FIELD-OTHERFIELD = COND #( WHEN ENTITY-NROOMS = 3 THEN IF_ABAP_BEHV=>FC-O-DISABLED ELSE IF_ABAP_BEHV=>FC-O-DISABLED )
) ).

Use IN LOCAL MODE to read current buffer state. %tky automatically includes all entity key fields to uniquely identify instances in transactional buffer. In above example %FEATURES-%FIELD-OTHERFIELD controls the state of UI elements & ENTITY-NROOMS will contain the new/changed value at runtime.

Regarding, retrigger the features control after determination on modify

determination onMyFieldChange on modify { field NRooms; }

above statement will trigger method GET_INSTANCE_FEATURES first & then determination method onMyFieldChange

entry.title: Re: #CoE#GB Display changes to object no value in SAP Pub...
entry.content:
Hi,

Please check following possible causes and diagnostic steps,

Possible Root Causes

  1. Change Document Configuration Missing: Object types may not have change documents properly activated
  2. App Replacement: The "Display Changes to Object" app may have been deprecated or replaced with newer functionality
  3. Object Type Not Included: Info records and PRs may not be included in the current logging scope
  4. User Authorization Restrictions: Insufficient permissions to view change logs for specific object types
  5. Alternative Change Tracking Method Required: Different apps or methods needed for specific object types
  6. System Configuration Gaps: Event logging activation may not cover all required object types

Diagnostic Steps

  1. Verify Change Document Apps: Check if you're using the correct app - the "Show Change Documents" app (CA_SHOW_CD) is the standard replacement for older change document functionality 
  2. Check Object-Specific Configuration: For info records, verify if change documents are activated for purchasing objects in customizing
  3. Validate App Access: Ensure you have proper authorization to access change document applications
  4. Review Object Type Coverage: Confirm that info records and PRs are included in your system's change document scope
  5. Test with Known Changes: Try viewing change documents for other object types to verify app functionality

 

Best regards,

Yong

entry.title: Architecture Decisions for Product Tracking and Tracing Capability
entry.content:
Summary

When defining a target architecture based on the SAP Reference Business Architecture (RBA), the Product Tracking and Tracing capability under the Supply Chain Enablement domain ensures product identification, serialization, and traceability across manufacturing, warehousing, logistics, and regulatory processes.

SAP Reference Business Architecture lists multiple solutions that support this capability —

1. SAP Advanced Track and Trace for Pharmaceuticals (ATTP)

2. SAP Auto-ID Infrastructure (Auto-ID)

3. SAP Corporate Serialization (CS).

This article provides architectural guidance for selecting the most suitable solution based on business requirements, industry regulations, and integration scope.

Business Requirements

The Product Tracking and Tracing capability is defined as the ability to uniquely identify, serialize, and track products through their lifecycle — from production to end-customer — ensuring compliance, authenticity, and operational visibility.

Key business drivers include:

  • Regulatory compliance (e.g., DSCSA, EU FMD for pharmaceuticals).
  • Country-specific legal requirements on serialization, tracking and tracing and regulatory reporting requirements of pharmaceutical products.
  • Serialization and aggregation at packaging levels.
  • Event-Based Object Tracking and Real-Time Visibility.
  • Tracking events from production, warehousing, transport, and distribution channels.
  • Data capture from IoT devices (e.g., RFID, barcodes).

The target solution must provide a standardized, scalable approach to handle product identification and data exchange across global supply chains.

Solution Options

The following SAP solutions are available to fulfil this capability:

  • SAP Advanced Track and Trace for Pharmaceuticals (ATTP)
  • SAP Auto-ID Infrastructure (Auto-ID)
  • SAP Corporate Serialization (CS)

Characterization of the Solution Options

1. SAP Advanced Track and Trace for Pharmaceuticals (ATTP)

  • Solution built for regulated industries such as pharmaceuticals and life sciences.
  • Provides country-specific legal requirements on serialization, tracking and tracing and regulatory reporting of pharmaceutical products (e.g., US DSCSA, EU FMD, Russia, Brazil, China).
  • Enables integration with packaging lines, Level 3 site systems, and national regulatory hubs.
  • Offers prebuilt interfaces to SAP ICH (Information Collaboration Hub for Life Sciences) for reporting to external authorities.
  • Ideal for compliance-driven serialization where regulatory reporting and verification are mandatory.

Integration Landscape:

SAP ATTP integrates tightly with SAP S/4HANA, SAP Manufacturing Execution (ME), SAP EWM and external line controllers. It leverages SAP BTP for data exchange and partner integrations.

2. SAP Auto-ID Infrastructure (Auto-ID)

  • Provides the foundational IoT framework for managing unique identifiers (e.g., barcodes, RFID, EPCIS events).
  • Tracks physical object movements and states across enterprise systems and locations.
  • Enables event capture and real-time analytics on serialized products.
  • Not limited to pharmaceuticals — applicable across industries like Consumer Goods, Automotive, and High Tech for asset tracking, warehouse automation, and IoT-enabled supply chain visibility.
  • Suitable for organizations seeking broader object event management rather than strict regulatory serialization.

Integration Landscape:

SAP Auto-ID Infrastructure is often deployed within SAP Supply Chain Execution or Digital Manufacturing landscapes. It integrates with SAP EWM and SAP Event Management for real-time visibility and object event tracking. In many architectures, it also participates in the broader transportation visibility chain (via EM integration into SAP TM).]

3. SAP Corporate Serialization (CS)

  • Provides a unique identifier repository to track and trace serialized products, ensuring end-to-end visibility across the global supply chain.
  • Manages enterprise-wide serialization data centrally within corporate IT landscapes, consolidating inputs from multiple plants, CMOs, and regional systems.
  • Integrates with SAP ATTP, SAP Auto-ID Infrastructure, and external serialization platforms, enabling seamless data synchronization and compliance oversight.
  • Supports global governance and policy enforcement by harmonizing serialization processes, regulatory data, and master data across sites within a unified compliance framework.
  • Offers centralized control over serialization data and lifecycle events, enhancing traceability, counterfeit prevention, and regulatory adherence.
  • Ideal for large, multi-site enterprises requiring centralized orchestration of serialization data and enterprise-level compliance monitoring.

Integration Landscape:

SAP Corporate Serialization acts as a master serialization repository and often coexists with SAP ATTP or Auto-ID instances in hybrid architectures. 

Criteria to determine the most suitable target solution

The decision on which product to implement for Product Tracking and Tracing depends on the industry context, regulatory scope, and operational maturity of the enterprise.

 

Criteria

SAP ATTP

SAP Auto-ID Infrastructure

SAP Corporate Serialization

Industry Focus

Life Sciences, Pharma

Cross-industry (Consumer Goods, Automotive, High Tech)

Multi-industry / Corporate IT

Primary Purpose

Regulatory compliance and serialization reporting

Object event management and IoT tracking

Centralized serialization master and governance

Compliance Requirement

Mandatory reporting to national authorities

Not compliance-driven

Corporate-level compliance consolidation

Integration Focus

Packaging lines, national hubs, SAP S/4HANA, SAP ICH

EWM, TM, Manufacturing, IoT sensors

ATTP, Auto-ID, external CMO networks

Complexity

High (regulatory + technical)

Moderate

High (multi-system orchestration)

 

Decision Tree

Conclusion

The Product Tracking and Tracing capability is essential for modern supply chains, enabling compliance, visibility, and trust. While SAP S/4HANA remains the operational backbone, the choice among SAP ATTP, SAP Auto-ID Infrastructure and SAP Corporate Serialization depends on:

  • Industry regulatory obligations
  • Scope of serialization or event tracking
  • Scale and governance model

In practice:

  • SAP ATTP is the default choice for regulated industries where compliance and reporting are mandatory.
  • SAP Auto-ID Infrastructure suits organizations focusing on real-time operational visibility.
  • SAP Corporate Serialization becomes critical for large enterprises consolidating multiple serialization environments.

Together, these solutions enable a scalable, compliant, and intelligent traceability architecture across industries — ensuring every serialized product can be trusted, tracked, and verified from source to shelf.

entry.title: Adopting UX best practices for intelligent applications in SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
In SAP projects, UX can quietly make or break the value of intelligent applications.  The thing is, many great ideas never land with business users because the layout is noisy, insights are buried, or the app just doesn’t feel “on brand.”

In this live session, “Adopting UX best practices for intelligent applications in SAP Business Data Cloud,” we’ll walk SAP partners through a reference intelligent application and show, step by step, how to:

  • Extend the app to surface new, meaningful insights
  • Tune layouts for clarity, consistency, and faster decisions
  • Choose chart types that actually fit the use case
  • Customize themes to mirror your customer’s brand identity

Content is adapted from internal SAP training and tailored specifically for partners, across roles—from consultants and designers to architects and developers.

If you’re looking to confidently extend today’s intelligent apps and prepare to build your own in SAP Business Data Cloud, this session is for you.

entry.title: Inventory Audit Report Performance Issue – Extremely Long Runtime / Timeouts (SAP Business One)
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am looking for assistance with a performance issue related to the Inventory Audit Report in SAP Business One.

System Landscape

  • SAP Business One Version: 10.0 FP 2405

  • Database: Microsoft SQL Server 2019

  • Database Size: ~57 GB

  • Server OS: Microsoft Windows Server 2019 Standard

  • Server Deployment: Cloud

  • Client Type: SAP Business One Windows Client

Issue Description

The client is experiencing very long execution times when running the standard Inventory Audit Report.

  • The report takes an excessive amount of time to load and frequently times out.

  • This behavior occurs even when running the report for a single day.

  • Due to the long runtime and timeout behavior, the report is effectively unusable.

  • The issue is consistent and reproducible.

Additional Observations

  • No customizations or modifications have been made to the standard Inventory Audit Report.

  • The issue occurs regardless of the user executing the report.

  • Other inventory-related reports execute normally or significantly faster in comparison.

  • Although the database contains historical inventory data, the issue still occurs with very small date ranges.

Business Impact

The Inventory Audit Report is required for:

  • Inventory reconciliation

  • Audit and compliance activities

  • Historical stock movement validation

At this time, the client cannot rely on this report due to the performance limitations.

Request for Assistance

We would appreciate guidance on:

  • Known performance issues with the Inventory Audit Report in SAP Business One 10 FP 2405

  • SAP Notes or known corrections related to this report

  • Recommended configuration or best practices to improve performance

  • Whether this behavior has been addressed in later Feature Packs or patches

Any insights, recommendations, or shared experiences would be highly appreciated.

Thank you

entry.title: BTP ABAP SaaS Solution: Custom Field not available in multitenant solution
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

We are developing a multitenant SaaS application in the BTP ABAP Environment using RAP.

We followed the official documentation for predefined field enablement:
https://help.sap.com/docs/abap-cloud/abap-development-tools-user-guide/working-with-predefined-field-enablings

Scenario:

  • RAP-based business object
  • Interface view marked as extensible
  • Dummy field added as described in the documentation
  • Application deployed in provider tenant
  • On the consumer tenant, a custom field is defined using the Predefined Custom Fields app

Issue:

  • In the "Configure Predefined Custom Fields" app on the consumer system, no services are available for selection in the "Services" section:
  • As a result the custom field can be defined, but the extended field does not appear in the application and is also not available in the Key User Extensibility tools and the metadata.

Implementation details:

  • Interface View Entity
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
@AbapCatalog.extensibility: {
  extensible: true,
  dataSources: ['Employee']
}
define root view entity /TCON/I_EMPLOYEE
  as select from /tcon/employee as Employee
{
  key uuid      as Uuid,
      firstname as FirstName,
      lastname  as LastName
}
  • View Extension
extend view entity /TCON/I_EMPLOYEE with
{
  Employee./tcon/custom_field_1
}
  • Persistence Include (Dummy Field)
@EndUserText.label : 'Extension structure for Employee'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #EXTENSIBLE_ANY
define structure /tcon/employee_ext_incl {
  dummy : abap.char(1);
}
​
  • Persistence Extension
extend type /tcon/employee_ext_incl with /tcon/employee_ext_incl_ext {
  /tcon/custom_field_1 : abap.char(1);
}
  • Predefined Field Enabling:
{
 "formatVersion":"1",
 "header":
 {
  "description":"Predefined Field Enabling for CDS entity /TCON/I_EMPLOYEE",
  "masterLanguage":"EN",
  "abapLanguageVersion":"cloudDevelopment"
 },
 "persistence":
 {
  "databaseTable":"/TCON/EMPLOYEE",
  "persistenceInclude":"/TCON/EMPLOYEE_EXT_INCL",
  "persistenceExtension":"/TCON/EMPLOYEE_EXT_INCL_EXT",
  "fieldPrefix":"/tcon/custom"
 },
 "predefinedFields":
 [
  {
   "name":"/tcon/custom_field_1",
   "type":"character",
   "length":1
  }
 ],
 "relatedViewEntities":
 [
  {
   "viewEntity":"/TCON/I_EMPLOYEE",
   "baseObjectAlias":"EMPLOYEE",
   "viewExtension":"/TCON/I_EMPLOYEE_EXT"
  }
 ],
 "serviceConsumptionModels":
 []
}​

Question:

Is predefined field enablement for RAP-based entities supported in multitenant ABAP Environment scenarios (provider/consumer setup)?
If yes, are there additional prerequisites (e.g. service bindings, service consumption models, or extensibility-related annotations) that must be maintained so that services become selectable in the Predefined Custom Fields app?

Any clarification would be highly appreciated.

Kind regards
Johannes
